What is Architectural Refactoring?

An Architectural Refactoring is a guideline to implement a quality improving measure in a software system. Based on symptoms (Smells), someone will try to find the cause of the deterioration in the system and a suitable improvement. An Architectural Refactoring is not an entirely self explaining guidance for the realisation, but it contains a summary of the change and a list of the most relevant execution tasks as well as several references. The following table describes the structure of an Architectural Refactoring.

Name

Short concise description of the Architectural Refactoring.

Status

Allowed are the following status: draft, in Review, accepted, published, deprecated, (unspecified)

Context (viewpoint, refinement level)

Contains a list of addressed viewpoints (e.g. functional view from 4+1 View Model of Philippe Kruchten) or refinement Levels, e.g. software level.

Quality attributes (forces)

A list of affected quality attributes.

Smells (refactoring drivers)

A Smell is a symptom in a software system which points to a drawback. The Smell always references an affected quality attribute.

Description

The description contains a summary of the problem (initial position), the procedure how the design should be optimised (revised design) and a list of pitfalls to avoid, which are points to pay attention to.

Architectural decision(s) to be revisited

A list of former design decisions which have to be reviewed based on the specific Architectural Refactoring. E.g. the choice of a middleware component.

Affected components and connectors (if modelled explicitly)

A list of components which are affected by the realisation of the Architectural Refactoring. E.g. the business software.

Execution tasks

The execution tasks are the interface to the projectoriented realisation of the Architectural Refactoring. There are several types of execution tasks. E.g "Design Task", "Development Task" or "Testing Task".

References (links)

The references are an important part of the Architectural Refactorings. Since an Architectural Refactoring does not contain an exhaustive description of the refactoring it is necessary to have guidance to additional knowledge.
